messageBody:
Hi guys,

I appreciate all the feedback I am getting. I understand that TDD is
a design activity , however what I wish to tackle is the test-first
concept of TDD. I realise that there are many phases to TDD, but it
seems what people have problems with is the idea of writing the
tests before writing the code. With that in mind, I figured if i
could help autogenerate some basic testing codes to get them off on
a start, they could get the hang of it and probably improve on the
tests generated later.



Erm does that make sense?


Most other tools out there requires additional installation etc,
which is why I hope to build on JUnit's core code itself to generate
the additional test cases. In such a way, the user probably won't
need any additional application, just an updated version of the
JUnit jar file for eclipse plugin or whatever?

I am kinda new at this and would appreciate any help or suggestions

Thanks a bunch,
Jimm
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Andrew McDonagh" <andrewmcdonagh@...>
wrote:
>
> On 12/27/06, chet hendrickson <lists@...> wrote:
> > Hello Jimm,
> >
> > I can imagine some benefit from generating some asserts as part
of the
> > second or third pass of test creation. Remember that TDD is a
> > /design/ activity, not a testing activity. I am afraid that
generated
> > assertions would break the basic cycle feedback of TDD.
> >
> > I am not going to tell you not to do this project, but calling
it TDD
> > would cause me to call into question your understanding of TDD.
> >
> > chet
>
> Agreed, essentially Jim, what you are describing (to me at least)
is
> automating the unit testing of code. It does not sound like TDD.
>
> And there's nothing wrong with that - JUnit is a tool that makes no
> assumptions on what design process we use.
>
> Indeed, there are already several tools out there that can
> autogenerate JUnit tests for code, and still others that 'play'
with
> the byte code to see if your unit tests are actually any good at
> testing. However, none of these tools are aimed at TDD, they are
> aimed at Unit Testing.
>
> hth
>
> Good luck with the course
>
> Andrew
>
